awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Building a Computational Thinking Foundation in Upper Elementary Science with Narrative-Centered Maker Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Introducing students to computational thinking is critical for workforce development. Because the elementary grades are a crucial time for developing students' dispositions toward STEM, integrating computational thinking into elementary students' science coursework is of paramount importance. The project centers on the design, development, and investigation of InfuseCS, an interactive learning environment for computational thinking that features maker-based digital storytelling and problem-based learning. Students will be introduced to computational thinking by working together in small groups to conduct computational model-based scientific investigations and creating narrative programs that generate interactive science narratives. The project will advance understanding of how to help upper elementary students learn about computational thinking in the context of science by conducting studies of students using the InfuseCS interactive learning environment in public elementary schools in California and North Carolina. 

The project will investigate how problem-based learning and computational thinking can be integrated with maker-based digital storytelling to create effective and engaging learning experiences in physical science. In conjunction with this investigation, the project will also explore how to best support teachers implementing narrative-centered maker activities that are deeply infused with problem-based learning. The project will have three thrusts. First, it will see the design and iterative refinement of the InfuseCS narrative-centered maker environment, which will be implemented at partner elementary schools in California and North Carolina. Second, it will develop, implement, and refine professional development materials for upper elementary school teachers. The professional development will include both face-to-face and online activities with the goal of preparing teachers to use the narrative-centered maker environment effectively and with fidelity in their classrooms. Third, the project will conduct focus groups, semi-structured interviews, classroom observations, and classroom implementation studies in the co-design of the narrative-centered maker environment. The project will investigate how the narrative-centered maker environment supports students in developing improved computational thinking competencies, improved understanding of disciplinary core ideas in physical science, and improved attitudes toward computational thinking and science.

The project is funded by the STEM + Computing Program, which seeks to study the applied integration of computational thinking and computing within disciplinary STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (PreK-12).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Integrating computational thinking into elementary education offers significant potential to enhance interdisciplinary learning. The InfuseCS project advanced understanding of how to embed computational thinking into upper elementary physical science instruction through a narrative-centered, problem-based learning approach. The project focused on the design and investigation of InfuseCS, an interactive learning environment that engages students in solving physical science problems by conducting scientific investigations and creating block-based, interactive digital narratives. Developed in collaboration with teachers and students in North Carolina and California, the learning environment enables students to explore science concepts through interactive simulations, engage in hands-on maker activities to investigate physical science phenomena, and apply their understanding by programming interactive narratives that visualize their reasoning. Through iterative design-based research and classroom studies, the project refined the learning environment and curriculum to align with both the Next Generation Science Standards and the K-12 Computer Science Framework. A culminating study involving over 800 students demonstrated significant learning gains in both physical science and computational thinking, highlighting the potential of narrative-centered, computationally-rich learning environments to support interdisciplinary STEM education in upper elementary grades.

Broader Impacts

The InfuseCS project made important contributions to elementary STEM education by providing engaging, age-appropriate tools for integrating science and computational thinking in diverse classroom settings. The project supported the professional growth of upper elementary teachers, many with limited prior experience in computational thinking, through co-design activities and professional development sessions focused on interdisciplinary instruction. Teachers reported increased confidence and adapted the materials to support a range of learners, including English Language Learners. The project also offered valuable training for graduate students in education and computer science, contributing to the development of future researchers and practitioners. In response to significant disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, the learning environment and materials were successfully adapted for remote access and low-performance devices, ensuring continuity of research and broader accessibility. By combining digital storytelling, science simulations, and hands-on maker activities, InfuseCS fostered student creativity, engagement, and scientific reasoning. The project's findings and tools offer a scalable model for integrating computational thinking into elementary science instruction and advancing STEM learning opportunities for all students.
